Ahmed Imtiaz Humayun

I am a third year PhD student at Rice University, where I work on deep learning theory and generative modeling, advised by Dr. Richard Baraniuk.

My interests lie in interpretation and improvement of deep neural network models via approximation theory, e.g., spline theory. I have received the Lowernstein Fellowship at Rice and have previously published in ICLR, Interspeech and JBHI to name a few. I also captain Bengali.AI, a group of passionate vigilante researchers devoted to the advancement of Bengali language technology.

Email  /  CV  /  Google Scholar  /  Twitter  /  Github

Research

My research transects the domains of computer vision, machine learning, optimization, and signal processing. Some of my representative projects are listed below.

Polarity Sampling: Quality and Diversity Control of Pre-Trained Generative Networks via Singular Values
Ahmed Imtiaz Humayun, Randall Balestriero, Richard Baraniuk
Under Review, 2022
project page / arXiv / video

We present a provable method, for controllable generation based on quality and diversity from any pre-trained deep generative model. We present results showing that only by increasing the sampling diversity of pretrained generative models, we can surpass previously reported SOTA image generation metrics.
MaGNET: Uniform Sampling from Deep Generative Network Manifolds Without Retraining
Ahmed Imtiaz Humayun, Randall Balestriero, Richard Baraniuk
ICLR, 2022
codes / arXiv / video

Inconsistencies and imbalance in the training data are reproduced when sampling from generative models, which could have dire effects, e.g., for fairness or data augmentation. In response, we develop a novel and theoretically motivated latent space sampler for any pre-trained DGN, that produces samples uniformly distributed on the learned manifold.

No More Than 6ft Apart: Robust K-Means via Radius Upper Bounds
Ahmed Imtiaz Humayun, Randall Balestriero, Anastasios Kyrillidis, Richard Baraniuk
ICASSP, 2022
codes / arXiv

Real world datasets often contain inherent abnormalities, e.g., repeated samples and sampling bias, that manifest imbalanced clustering via K-methods. We propose to remedy such a scenario by introducing a maximal radius constraint on the clusters, i.e., samples from the same cluster should not be more than 2r apart in terms of l2 distance.


Yet another steal of Jon Barron's amazing website.
